Submit your poem to the English 348 poetry anthology. See more details below. \n\nPoetry of place moves the reader from their current environment to another. The space described may be physical, emotional, or imaginative, and may be realized through specific details that transport the reader. \nEligibility: All current Texas A&M students and Blinn students are eligible.\n\nSubmit one or two unpublished, original poems to: creativewriting348900@gmail.com\nFor more information: j-mccann1@tamu.edu\nPoems must be a maximum of 32 lines each including title and spaces, or must fit into a space 3.7\" x 5\" (the size of an anthology page.)\n\nDeadline for submission is Oct 20. Each poem must have poet's name and contact information, and must indicate the sender's school name."}

We think they're cool.\n", "icon": "https://fbstatic-a.akamaihd.net/rsrc.php/v2/yD/r/aS8ecmYRys0.gif", "type": "photo", "id": "6069997491_458343357524474", "status_type": "shared_story", "description": "Geoffrey Kornegay\u2019s final graduate study at Texas A&M\u2019s Master of Architecture program won \u201cBest of the Best\u201d honors at the Department of Architecture\u2019s inaugural Celebration of Excellence May 11 at the College Station Hilton.\n\nHis project, a proposal for a network of facilities in Mexico City intended to encourage community connectivity, was one of five final study presentations made by fellow Master of Architecture students Dayna Finley, Kuangyi Tao, Jose Terrazas, and Mark Willingham.\n\nThe five students\u2019 projects, juried by a group of design professionals, were previously selected by department faculty as the academic year\u2019s top graduate study projects.\n\nOther graduate student award recipients were: Peri Arthur, presented with the Henry Adams Certificate; Akshay Sangolli, presented with the Henry Adams Medal; Amy Kircher, presented with the Alpha Rho Chi Medal and Pasquale de Paola, presented with the Architectural Research Centers Consortium\u2019s King Medal. \n\nUndergraduate students recognized with top integrated studio projects were Marquesa Figueroa, Troy Grant, Rick Hasner, Alex Holtzer, Andrew Horne, Michelle Huertas, Eric Opperman, Michael Rollins, Ellen Sampson and Rafael Vasquez.\n\nMichael O\u2019Brien, professor of architecture, and Shelley Holiday, senior architecture lecturer, were announced as recipients of graduate and undergraduate teaching awards, respectively, after a student vote.\n\n\u201cThese awards recognize not only our most promising students and their individual accomplishments, but also represent the level of excellence of all our students,\u201d said Ward Wells, head of the Department of Architecture. \u201cThe recognition of students and faculty is truly a cause for a celebration of excellence.\u201d\n"}

Don't let the cheesy, unassuming free blog hosting platform template fool you.\n\nThe problem is basically I have zero writing experience and yet created a secretly wildly successful prototype entertainment product that I'm not sure what to do with, so even trying to explain it to strangers without explaining the magic of how it works gets complicated.\n\nUmmm... The NCES will conduct the National Assessments of Adult Literacy (NAAL) in 2002. It will assess the current status of the English-language literacy skills of adults in the U.S., as well as indicate how literacy proficiencies have changed over time."}

Eye rhyme: words that look like they rhyme on paper but actually do not when they are read aloud (ex. \u201ccough\u201d and \u201cthough\u201d). Slant Rhyme: rhyme that is imperfect, typically in the vowel sounds (ex. \u201cdark\u201d and \u201cheart\u201d).", "type": "status", "id": "6069997491_135370576481276", "status_type": "mobile_status_update"}
